title: Record-setting turnout highlights Art, Beer and Wine Festival
content: JACKSON, MI - People came out in record numbers to the 14th annual Art Beer and Wine Festival, presented by County National Bank.     Festival Director Kyle Liechty said 5,000 attendees took part in the festival Saturday, June 2 at the Ella Sharp Museum, 3325 Fourth Street. Liechty said the total was 1,500 more people than last year and doubled the 2016 event.     After anticipating 4,500 people to attend this year's festival, Liechty said he was proud of the staff and volunteers who adjusted and responded to the high turnout.     "It's a perfect day," Liechty said. "It's great seeing so many people in the community at the museum. Everywhere you walk you see 100 people."     The festival, which raises money for museum programming, included 154 booths comprising many artists and vendors. Live music was also played.     Evan Struck, a sophomore at Western High School, hosted a pair of live speed painting demos at the festival. The 16-year-old was raising money to attend a summer art camp at the College for Creative Studies in Detroit.     Struck said he has been participating in speed painting for about two months. With people watching him work, he said he wasn't nervous.     "I'm focused in my whole kind of state," he said.     Local brewers on hand included Jackson-based 127 Brewing. Volunteer Tom Mitchell, 43, was one of many who poured drinks to guests.     "Everybody's hyped up - everybody's excited," Mitchell said.     Attendees walked around sampling drinks and purchasing art. Gabby Heida, a 25-year-old Hillsdale resident, asked her friend and 24-year-old- Grand Rapids resident Lyna Nguyen to come to the festival.     "This was worth the two-hour drive," Nguyen said.     The festival ran from 1 to 7 p.m.
